messages.text: I am plotting a graph with `plot` and then add several more lines with `plot!` . I want to use a color-blind friendly color palette, so instead of getting first a blue line, then green, then red, the lines would appear with different colors. I played around with the keywords `c` and `palette` , but all i achieved was that each line looked exactly the same, somewhat like a rainbow, consisting of all colors in the pallette. What's the correct way to do this?

attachments.text: I know itâ€™s been a while since this question was posted, but it took me a while to plot a choropleth from a DataFrame so Iâ€™ll post the way I do it by using Shapefile.jl and Plots.jl I hope this could help someone out there. The resulting map without working so much on the aesthetics is the following: using Plots using Shapefile using DataFrames using Colors #building a custom categorical colorbar colorbar = cgrad(["#FFFFFF", "#ffffcc", "#a1dab4", "#41b6c4", "#253494"], categorical = true) ...

messages.text:
Hi. I would like to include some vegalite.jl graphs in a markdown (via weave.jl) with the same interactive features as they have in the vscode julia extension (mainly the mouse over infos). I already tried to export the whole graph into a html (using  `VegaLite.writehtml_full`) or svg (`|> save("test2.svg")`)file. For the svg I get warnings while creating (e.g. `WARN Missing type for channel "x", using "quantitative" instead.`
`WARN Missing type for channel "tooltip", using "nominal" instead.`) and the file is empty in the end. For the html I get a working file however that shows the same error messages as the SVG in the browser console and the graph is broken (see attached screenshots).
Is there another way to do get the graphs into markdown with interactive features? Did I overlook something?
The code for the graph looks like this `df |> @vlplot(:boxplot, x = :x, y = :y, width=600, height=600)`
df has 2 columns, y is of Float64 and x is a CategoricalArray of Strings

messages.text: I have a case where I generate quite a number of graphs in julia, but to mark them according to type I then add a colored border around, see attached image. Previously I have done this manually, but it would be really useful if I could come up with a way to do this in julia (since I now want to generate quite a number of these). Is there such a way? At least making it a bit similar to this would be really useful.

elements.text: I have a case where I generate quite a number of graphs in julia, but to mark them according to type I then add a colored border around, see attached image. Previously I have done this manually, but it would be really useful if I could come up with a way to do this in julia (since I now want to generate quite a number of these). Is there such a way? At least making it a bit similar to this would be really useful.

messages.text:
If you're interested in trying this out in Makie, a very simple way would be this:
```using CairoMakie
let 
    f = Figure()

    for n in 1:4
        i, j = fldmod1(n, 2)
        f[i, j] = Box(f, color = :transparent, strokecolor = rand(RGBf0), strokewidth = 4)
        f[i, j] = Axis(f, alignmode = Outside(20))
        foreach(1:5) do i
            lines!(cumsum(randn(1000)), color = rand(RGBf0), linewidth = 2)
        end
    end
    f
end```
I just made a Box in each cell and placed the axis in the same cell with some padding. You can go more sophisticated but I was just curious to do this in a minute

elements.text: If you're interested in trying this out in Makie, a very simple way would be this:

using CairoMakie
let 
    f = Figure()

    for n in 1:4
        i, j = fldmod1(n, 2)
        f[i, j] = Box(f, color = :transparent, strokecolor = rand(RGBf0), strokewidth = 4)
        f[i, j] = Axis(f, alignmode = Outside(20))
        foreach(1:5) do i
            lines!(cumsum(randn(1000)), color = rand(RGBf0), linewidth = 2)
        end
    end
    f
end
I just made a Box in each cell and placed the axis in the same cell with some padding. You can go more sophisticated but I was just curious to do this in a minute

messages.text:
The font finding of makie is actually something I'm a bit proud of haha. Not because it was so hard to do, just because I was so annoyed by matplotlib's and other's font finding ability.

It works only by font name because in my experience it's annoying to get the combination of family, weight, style etc right just to select a font of which you already know the name. For example semibold fonts or other special types. In Makie you just write "myfont semibold". If you have ever sifted through matplotlib's auto generated font jsons just to find the sometimes wrongly determined parameters of your font so you can plug them back in to matplotlib you know how bad that can be.

And you don't have to write the name exactly because that's also annoying to get right. You can write "myfont semi" etc. I don't want to have to take a trip to the font manager just to look up the exact name of a font. There are some heuristics there which font gets chosen first that hopefully give the right results in most cases. I never documented it in Makie but maybe I should, just to clarify

root.text: How do I make plot labels Bold? Like I can make them larger, *`legendfontsize`* , but at some point they might get quite large (and take up lots of space), but I want the text to be *thicker*.

elements.text: How do I make plot labels Bold? Like I can make them larger,
legendfontsize
, but at some point they might get quite large (and take up lots of space), but I want the text to be
thicker

The font finding of makie is actually something I'm a bit proud of haha. Not because it was so hard to do, just because I was so annoyed by matplotlib's and other's font finding ability.

It works only by font name because in my experience it's annoying to get the combination of family, weight, style etc right just to select a font of which you already know the name. For example semibold fonts or other special types. In Makie you just write "myfont semibold". If you have ever sifted through matplotlib's auto generated font jsons just to find the sometimes wrongly determined parameters of your font so you can plug them back in to matplotlib you know how bad that can be.

And you don't have to write the name exactly because that's also annoying to get right. You can write "myfont semi" etc. I don't want to have to take a trip to the font manager just to look up the exact name of a font. There are some heuristics there which font gets chosen first that hopefully give the right results in most cases. I never documented it in Makie but maybe I should, just to clarify

messages.text:
I noticed some inconsistencies with `savefig` (Pyplot via Plots.jl). Sometimes the ticks overlap, and sometimes they don't. How do I avoid this?
```p = plot_iso(sol) # my custom function that uses plot and plot!
	savefig("1.png")
	savefig(p, "2.png")
	savefig("3.png")```

messages.text: Hello, people. Has anyone ever tried using <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isotype_(picture_language)|isotypes>/pictorial graphs in Julia? I don't know if the best thing I can do is use `using Images` load each pictogram and add each instance of the pictogram on Plots.jl or if there is any other (more intelligent and less time consuming) way. Any advice?

attachments.title: Isotype (picture language)
attachments.text: Isotype (International System of Typographic Picture Education) is a method of showing social, technological, biological, and historical connections in pictorial form. It consists of a set of standardized and abstracted pictorial symbols to represent social-scientific data with specific guidelines on how to combine the identical figures using serial repetition. It was first known as the Vienna Method of Pictorial Statistics (Wiener Methode der Bildstatistik), due to its having been developed at the Gesellschafts- und Wirtschaftsmuseum in Wien (Social and Economic Museum of Vienna) between 1925 and 1934. The founding director of this museum, Otto Neurath, was the initiator and chief theorist of the Vienna Method. Gerd Arntz was the artist responsible for realising the graphics. The term Isotype was applied to the method around 1935, after its key practitioners were forced to leave Vienna by the rise of Austrian fascism.
